title: Erdős #637: Distinct Degrees in Induced Subgraphs
description: If G on n vertices has no clique/independent set on ≫ log n vertices, then G contains an induced subgraph with ≫ √n distinct degrees. Bukh-Sudakov (2007) proved this; JKLY (2020) strengthened to ≫ n^{2/3} degrees.

meta.author: Paul Erdős, Faudree, Sós, Bukh, Sudakov, Jenssen, Keevash, Long, Yepremyan

overview.historicalContext: Erdős, Faudree, and Sós conjectured that graphs with small Ramsey numbers (no large cliques or independent sets) must have induced subgraphs with many distinct degrees. This connects degree diversity to Ramsey-theoretic properties.
overview.problemStatement: If G on n vertices has ω(G), α(G) = O(log n), then G contains an induced subgraph on ≫ n vertices with ≫ √n distinct degrees. Bukh-Sudakov (2007) proved this. JKLY (2020) improved to ≫ n^{2/3} degrees without vertex count restriction.
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize vertex degrees, distinct degree counts, Ramsey graph properties, induced subgraphs, the original conjecture, the Bukh-Sudakov solution, the JKLY strengthening, optimality considerations, and connections to Ramsey theory.
keyInsights: Ramsey graphs: ω(G), α(G) = O(log n)
Bukh-Sudakov (2007): ≫ √n distinct degrees in induced subgraph
JKLY (2020): ≫ n^{2/3} distinct degrees (no vertex restriction)
Random G(n, 1/2) is typically a Ramsey graph

sections.title: Basic Definitions
sections.summary: Vertex degrees and distinct degree counts

conclusion.summary: This formalization captures Erdős Problem #637 on distinct degrees in induced subgraphs of Ramsey graphs. The problem was solved by Bukh-Sudakov (2007) and strengthened by JKLY (2020).
conclusion.implications: The results reveal a fundamental connection between Ramsey-theoretic properties (absence of large cliques/independent sets) and degree diversity in graphs.
openQuestions: What is the exact constant in the JKLY bound?
Can the result be extended to hypergraphs?
